description:
Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. 

There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.
name: NURSING OF CHILDREN: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

Students commented that this was the “first class at the nursing school that taught… how to think like a nurse.” Most students thought there was a large amount of work to be done especially for the clinical portion. However, one student stated that she “learned more from doing the [clinical assignments] and learning through case studies.” A common opinion was that the class should incorporate more “normal values”, pathophysiology, and child development since some students have not had this information before. The overall feeling was that the course offered a good “perspective on pediatric nursing that will be extremely helpful in the future.”

Professor Hickerson “was a tremendous lecturer” who made it easy for students to be engaged in the class. Students felt Professor Hickerson made “all the material interesting.” One of the best things was that Professor Hickerson “rotated through clinical sites regularly to check in and engage students.” The class was enhanced by Professor Hickerson’s examples of clinical application and interactive lecture sessions.

Most students did not feel the exams were fair or well written. The tests covered minute details instead of the bigger picture which students did not appreciate. The clinical databases required a good amount of time but were worth an appropriate percentage of the grade. One student felt the textbook was great; however, other students did not feel the exemplar readings at the beginning of the class were as helpful as the text. The extra credit simulations allowed students not only to improve their grades but also their assessment and critical thinking skills. This course is required of all junior nursing students. The prerequisites include N104, N106, N131, N132.

Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

Students commented that this was the “first class at the nursing school that taught… how to think like a nurse.” Most students thought there was a large amount of work to be done especially for the clinical portion. However, one student stated that she “learned more from doing the [clinical assignments] and learning through case studies.” A common opinion was that the class should incorporate more “normal values”, pathophysiology, and child development since some students have not had this information before. The overall feeling was that the course offered a good “perspective on pediatric nursing that will be extremely helpful in the future.”

Professor Curley, in one student’s opinion, was “amazing in terms of what she knows and her ability to relay it to students in an applicable and approachable way.” Other comments were similar in saying that Professor Curley was very accessible, extremely knowledgeable, and “passionate about the field.” Though, there was one student who did not appreciate how Professor Curley “seems to pick on what [students] do not know instead of teaching us.” Overall, students felt Professor Curley was helpful and inspiring.

Most students did not feel the exams were fair or well written. The tests covered minute details instead of the bigger picture which students did not appreciate. The clinical databases required a good amount of time but were worth an appropriate percentage of the grade. One student felt the textbook was great; however, other students did not feel the exemplar readings at the beginning of the class were as helpful as the text. The extra credit simulations allowed students not only to improve their grades but also their assessment and critical thinking skills. This course is required of all junior nursing students. The prerequisites include N104, N106, N131, N132.

Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

Students commented that this was the “first class at the nursing school that taught… how to think like a nurse.” Most students thought there was a large amount of work to be done especially for the clinical portion. However, one student stated that she “learned more from doing the [clinical assignments] and learning through case studies.” A common opinion was that the class should incorporate more “normal values”, pathophysiology, and child development since some students have not had this information before. The overall feeling was that the course offered a good “perspective on pediatric nursing that will be extremely helpful in the future.”

Professor Connolly was “clearly devoted and interested in the class.’ Students thought Professor Connolly was “available and compassionate.” One student “would have liked to learn more” from Professor Connolly’s policy lecture since it was an interesting topic “but took too long to get to the point.” The overall consensus is that Professor Connolly “cared a great deal about students’ development and experience in the class.”

Most students did not feel the exams were fair or well written. The tests covered minute details instead of the bigger picture which students did not appreciate. The clinical databases required a good amount of time but were worth an appropriate percentage of the grade. One student felt the textbook was great; however, other students did not feel the exemplar readings at the beginning of the class were as helpful as the text. The extra credit simulations allowed students not only to improve their grades but also their assessment and critical thinking skills. This course is required of all junior nursing students. The prerequisites include N104, N106, N131, N132.
